HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY

SIGMA UPSILON TO
HAND IN CHARTER
Sigma Upsilon, the only
national literary fraternity
at Hopkins, has decided to
turn in its charter. According to Jesse Slingluff, the
chief reason for the decline
in interest in the fraternity
has been the increased activity of the Tudor and Stuart
Club, a like organization.
Nearly all the members of
Sigma Upsilon are also members of the Tudor and Stuart
Club.
Members of the Hopkins
chapter are Hiss, Turnbull,
Hopkins, Strathman, Slingluff, Hood, Wales, and Taylor.

DR. SINGEWALD DESCRIBES
ADVENTUROUS TRIP IN
SOUTH AMERICA
Geologist, In Illustrated Lecture,
Recounts Thrilling Expedition
Up The Amazon

-What happens to geologists in
out of the way parts of the world
gave rise to the remark that in
the halcyon days of the western
frontier those with a taste for adventure became cowboys, but in
the present day the same spirits
become geologists," was the prefatory remarks of Dr. J. T. Singewald, Professor of Geology at
Johns Hopkins, in an illustrated
talk at the Assembly, last Thursday.

12, 1926.

PLANS OUTLINED
FOR CELEBRATION

The plans for the Commemoration Day exercises, to be
held February 22, include an
address at the Peabody Institute by Dr. M. I. Pupin
during the forenoon, an inspection of buildings during
the afternoon, and an Alumni
rally in the evening.
Dr. Pupin, Professor of
Electro-Mechanics at Columbia University and President
of the American Association
for the Advancement of Science will deliver his address
on the subject of "Intellectual Renaissance."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 12, 1926.

TOUGH LUCK BLUE JAY
With a crashing of cymbals the Black and Blue Jay broke
into the public prints of the city. The "Jay" was naughty,
at times it approached the salacious—at least that was the implication that prevailed in the public mind when the Christmas
edition was barred from the precincts of Goucher College. It
was not fit for the fair and innocent damsels that inhabit the
district below Twenty-fifth Street,—at least that is what the
papers implied.
The Business Staff of the "Jay" was in ecstacies ; circulation would soon be on the increase; the editors would soon
roll in the lap of luxury. The fabled good times had come with
a vengeance.
And then Dr. Guth'broke the bubble. "Not naughty, just a
nuisance," he said. He knew that the minds of the Goucher
damsels could not be contaminated by anything as innocuous as
the "Jay"; they were far beyond such a puerile stage. It was
not naughty, it was a nuisance.
All of which was tough luck. It was too ha
. d that Dr. Guth
could not find fault with the content of the magazine. It was
too darned bad. The circulation of the dear old "Jay" will not
increase so rapidly as had been expected.
If the NEWS-LETTER may be so rash as to make a suggestion
—make a snappy number, just risque enough to attract the
attention of the Comstocks, get your magazine barred from the
mails, and watch the prosperity begin to roll in. It worked
wonders at Harvard. But don't try to get the Goucher Goat.
That college is too advanced; too liberal.

DODGE, BRETHREN, DODGE
Through preternatural agility the editor of this so-called
paper has just preserved his worthless life. Two unoffending
students who were walking with him went to a premature
grave, crushed and mangled. And all because the walks and
drives of Homewood were not made for the simultaneous use
of pedestrians and fast traveling automobiles.
There is no doubt about it,—the drive from the Barn to
Gilman Hall should either be made wider, or sidewalks constructed. The present situation makes one's life worth little
if he dare to traverse that thoroughfare during the scholastic
rush hours. If the pedestrian is not unusually quick upon his
feet, he stands a good chance of being used as a bumper for a
collegiate flivver, or knocked off by a bloated plutocrat in a fur
coat and a Packard. For the proletariat life is an unsafe and
hazardous occupation.
Please, oh, please, Messrs. Board of 'I rustees, please give
us sidewalks.

YES and NO
Less than a meal ago we remembered with a groan that we
were -expected to produce a column for this issue. We felt
sunk. No time. No energy. No mood for it. Worse, nothing
to write about.
"Oh, well," we sighed, getting a grip on ourself, "we can
write about activities. There are other things to be sarcastic
about besides class officers,—the whole lot of activities, in fact.
For instance, we can start with our opinion of the managerships
of sports. And, more politely, we can say what we think about
anybody who goes out for such activities."
"We can go on to point out, acutely, the circular nature
of the rewards of these jobs, in showing that the assistantmanagers- crave the managerships for two reasons, exclusive of
fraternity approbation: the actual slender pleasures to be
found in the exercise of the duties of the office, and the envy and
respect of the campus. Then we can mention that the undergraduate respects the manager partly because of the meager
spoils of the victory, and partly because the rest of the campus
shares this respectful attitude, but chiefly because the manager
himself feels that he has achieved something which deserves the
respect of the campus."
"In other words,",we mused away,"the original respectability of the activity derived from the slightly envious contemplation of the rewards, which in turn increased the joys of the
possessor. As this mutual respect became increasingly 'functionally reciprocal,' the-managerships attracted more ambitious
souls who quite naturally accelerated the process with their
egotism. Today, competition is keen for the managerships because the undergraduates have inherited the respectful attitude their predecessors assumed mainly because the managers
themselves respected the opinion of the undergraduates."
"And then," we continued to ourself, warming to our devilish scheme, we can paint a gruesome picture of the degrading
aspects of this activity. And we can sorrowfully ponder over
its importance in the eyes of 0. D. K. Indeed, we can go on to
reveal the degradation lurking in all of the other activities.
In each case, we can permit ourself to wonder what 0. D. K. can
see in it. And finally, soaring swiftly to our climax, we can ask
of 0. D. K. what ft can possibly see in 0. D. K.!"
"If we live thru this heresy, we may even follow with a
philosophically toleraht epilogue to the effect that activities,
after all, are all right for those who like them. Altho, of course,
we must confess that such people ..."
"But ye editor said we should be LITERARY !", we recalled
with a shock.
"Oh, bologna!", we revolted, with admirable orthography,
-we must write about something."
"What do we mean—'we must write about something'", we
savagely demanded of ourself.
Why must we? Why do we
write the column, anyway?"
"Oh, it interests and amuses us. And it's good for us. Of
course, it would be better for us if we tackled some more ambitious type of writing. And it would be vastly more interesting.
But, dammit, we never give ourself time to be 'literary,' and we
refuse to be merely a fraction thereof."
"All of which is quite true," we answered ourself, severely,
"but we are not getting anywhere with this week's column."
"Yes," we replied, glumly, "that's the truth, despite the
fact that we have finally written the column."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY

SIGMA UPSILON TO
HAND IN CHARTER
Sigma Upsilon, the only
national literary fraternity
at Hopkins, has decided to
turn in its charter. According to Jesse Slingluff, the
chief reason for the decline
in interest in the fraternity
has been the increased activity of the Tudor and Stuart
Club, a like organization.
Nearly all the members of
Sigma Upsilon are also members of the Tudor and Stuart
Club.
Members of the Hopkins
chapter are Hiss, Turnbull,
Hopkins, Strathman, Slingluff, Hood, Wales, and Taylor.

DR. SINGEWALD DESCRIBES
ADVENTUROUS TRIP IN
SOUTH AMERICA
Geologist, In Illustrated Lecture,
Recounts Thrilling Expedition
Up The Amazon

-What happens to geologists in
out of the way parts of the world
gave rise to the remark that in
the halcyon days of the western
frontier those with a taste for adventure became cowboys, but in
the present day the same spirits
become geologists," was the prefatory remarks of Dr. J. T. Singewald, Professor of Geology at
Johns Hopkins, in an illustrated
talk at the Assembly, last Thursday.

12, 1926.

PLANS OUTLINED
FOR CELEBRATION

The plans for the Commemoration Day exercises, to be
held February 22, include an
address at the Peabody Institute by Dr. M. I. Pupin
during the forenoon, an inspection of buildings during
the afternoon, and an Alumni
rally in the evening.
Dr. Pupin, Professor of
Electro-Mechanics at Columbia University and President
of the American Association
for the Advancement of Science will deliver his address
on the subject of "Intellectual Renaissance."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 12, 1926.

TOUGH LUCK BLUE JAY
With a crashing of cymbals the Black and Blue Jay broke
into the public prints of the city. The "Jay" was naughty,
at times it approached the salacious—at least that was the implication that prevailed in the public mind when the Christmas
edition was barred from the precincts of Goucher College. It
was not fit for the fair and innocent damsels that inhabit the
district below Twenty-fifth Street,—at least that is what the
papers implied.
The Business Staff of the "Jay" was in ecstacies ; circulation would soon be on the increase; the editors would soon
roll in the lap of luxury. The fabled good times had come with
a vengeance.
And then Dr. Guth'broke the bubble. "Not naughty, just a
nuisance," he said. He knew that the minds of the Goucher
damsels could not be contaminated by anything as innocuous as
the "Jay"; they were far beyond such a puerile stage. It was
not naughty, it was a nuisance.
All of which was tough luck. It was too ha
. d that Dr. Guth
could not find fault with the content of the magazine. It was
too darned bad. The circulation of the dear old "Jay" will not
increase so rapidly as had been expected.
If the NEWS-LETTER may be so rash as to make a suggestion
—make a snappy number, just risque enough to attract the
attention of the Comstocks, get your magazine barred from the
mails, and watch the prosperity begin to roll in. It worked
wonders at Harvard. But don't try to get the Goucher Goat.
That college is too advanced; too liberal.

DODGE, BRETHREN, DODGE
Through preternatural agility the editor of this so-called
paper has just preserved his worthless life. Two unoffending
students who were walking with him went to a premature
grave, crushed and mangled. And all because the walks and
drives of Homewood were not made for the simultaneous use
of pedestrians and fast traveling automobiles.
There is no doubt about it,—the drive from the Barn to
Gilman Hall should either be made wider, or sidewalks constructed. The present situation makes one's life worth little
if he dare to traverse that thoroughfare during the scholastic
rush hours. If the pedestrian is not unusually quick upon his
feet, he stands a good chance of being used as a bumper for a
collegiate flivver, or knocked off by a bloated plutocrat in a fur
coat and a Packard. For the proletariat life is an unsafe and
hazardous occupation.
Please, oh, please, Messrs. Board of 'I rustees, please give
us sidewalks.

YES and NO
Less than a meal ago we remembered with a groan that we
were -expected to produce a column for this issue. We felt
sunk. No time. No energy. No mood for it. Worse, nothing
to write about.
"Oh, well," we sighed, getting a grip on ourself, "we can
write about activities. There are other things to be sarcastic
about besides class officers,—the whole lot of activities, in fact.
For instance, we can start with our opinion of the managerships
of sports. And, more politely, we can say what we think about
anybody who goes out for such activities."
"We can go on to point out, acutely, the circular nature
of the rewards of these jobs, in showing that the assistantmanagers- crave the managerships for two reasons, exclusive of
fraternity approbation: the actual slender pleasures to be
found in the exercise of the duties of the office, and the envy and
respect of the campus. Then we can mention that the undergraduate respects the manager partly because of the meager
spoils of the victory, and partly because the rest of the campus
shares this respectful attitude, but chiefly because the manager
himself feels that he has achieved something which deserves the
respect of the campus."
"In other words,",we mused away,"the original respectability of the activity derived from the slightly envious contemplation of the rewards, which in turn increased the joys of the
possessor. As this mutual respect became increasingly 'functionally reciprocal,' the-managerships attracted more ambitious
souls who quite naturally accelerated the process with their
egotism. Today, competition is keen for the managerships because the undergraduates have inherited the respectful attitude their predecessors assumed mainly because the managers
themselves respected the opinion of the undergraduates."
"And then," we continued to ourself, warming to our devilish scheme, we can paint a gruesome picture of the degrading
aspects of this activity. And we can sorrowfully ponder over
its importance in the eyes of 0. D. K. Indeed, we can go on to
reveal the degradation lurking in all of the other activities.
In each case, we can permit ourself to wonder what 0. D. K. can
see in it. And finally, soaring swiftly to our climax, we can ask
of 0. D. K. what ft can possibly see in 0. D. K.!"
"If we live thru this heresy, we may even follow with a
philosophically toleraht epilogue to the effect that activities,
after all, are all right for those who like them. Altho, of course,
we must confess that such people ..."
"But ye editor said we should be LITERARY !", we recalled
with a shock.
"Oh, bologna!", we revolted, with admirable orthography,
-we must write about something."
"What do we mean—'we must write about something'", we
savagely demanded of ourself.
Why must we? Why do we
write the column, anyway?"
"Oh, it interests and amuses us. And it's good for us. Of
course, it would be better for us if we tackled some more ambitious type of writing. And it would be vastly more interesting.
But, dammit, we never give ourself time to be 'literary,' and we
refuse to be merely a fraction thereof."
"All of which is quite true," we answered ourself, severely,
"but we are not getting anywhere with this week's column."
"Yes," we replied, glumly, "that's the truth, despite the
fact that we have finally written the column."
